explanation:
Correct calculation: \( 3000 \, \text{ml} \div 1000 = 3 \, \text{liters} \).  
Student's error: \( 3000 \, \text{ml} \div 100 = 30 \, \text{liters} \).  

The student incorrectly divided by 100 instead of 1000, treating milliliters as if they convert to liters by a factor of 100. This stems from misapplying the metric prefix "milli-" (which denotes \( \frac{1}{1000} \)) as if it were "centi-" (\( \frac{1}{100} \)). Their reasoning conflated the conversion steps for different metric prefixes, leading to an answer 10 times too large.  

This error is distinct from thinking there are 10,000 ml in a liter (which would result in 0.3 liters) or multiplying instead of dividing (which would yield 3,000,000 liters). The specific misuse of the 100:1 ratio directly aligns with confusion between metric prefixes rather than arithmetic inversion or unit magnitude errors.
